This game is so pretty to look at, the components are very nice, the tree is nice (but absolutely unnecessary). In the gameplay, everyone plays the game for themselves and collects a few cards, here and there a combination is created for more points, sometimes someone snatches a card from you or occupies a space that you would have needed for your next combination... this is not player interaction, by the way. Since I discovered 18xx games, I know what player interaction means, it's moments where you want to go for the other player's throat at the same time and get a high five because his action was so brilliant, where you have to react to the other player's move, who in turn has to counteract it, and you have to react again yourself and so on.

Games like Everdell and alike, I get so bored of these types of games. Of course you can have a good time while you're playing it, but it's not the kind of thing where after a board game evening I think, wow that was a great evening, we learned a lot during the game and we'll have to find a new date for the next one soon!

I don't think it's a gatewaygame either that you could make appealing to non-players or players who don't play much, because it's too overloaded for that.

Worst game I have ever played, the tempo is incredible disguting when you can't have the only one action you need, and that everybody before you takes... then it's the end of the game. I really don't understand how this is that much loved, i think it is my worst board game experience

The balance between experienced players and new players is non-existent. 3 of us were on the third season while the owner of the game was still doing millions of actions in a chain fashion in season one.

With some expansions there are still games that have more elements on the board in a base versions that you still keep track on, whilst here I don't care and don't pay attention to 50% of elements on the board. It just happens.

Mir war von Anfang an klar, daß Everdell – rein mechanisch – das schlechteste meiner Kennerspiele ist. Ich behielt es, weil es, selbst bei Anfängern, sehr bekannt ist: Und diese, aufgrund der niedlichen Optik, schnell zu begeistern waren. Und dann waren da ja noch die ganzen Erweiterungen, die das Spiel, theoretisch, auch für mich attraktiver machen konnten.

Nun ist es aber endgültig Zeit, getrennte Wege zu gehen: Ständig nur darauf zu achten, ob man ein passendes Paar Karten hat, nervt genauso, wie das Auszählen der Punkte am Ende. Viele Texte sind zu klein, um am Tisch ergonomisch angeordnet zu werden. Wenn man es nicht regelmäßig spielt, muß man immer wieder irgendwelche Details in den Regeln nachlesen – und ohne Spirecrest will ich es eigentlich gar nicht mehr spielen, mit aber auch nicht (mehr dort).

Auch viele meiner Neulinge mussten letztlich einsehen, daß das Spiel zu schwer für Anfänger ist und auch längst nicht so gut, wie die hübsche Aufmachung verspricht.
A generic worker placement game. It was kind of boring. The art is amazing though.

A simple resource-conversion card-based engine-builder, very text-heavy, very heads-down. Your ability to perform is wildly throttled by card-search space, especially emphasized by constructions which each grant a stipend of 4 to 6 Berries (a fairly expensive resource) with which to build a specific Critter card. The intrinsic combos implied by these production chains and further special VP Events that are earned by building specific cards make the entire game feel more on-rails than most games of the sort.

Being that card-search is so important, the moving supply of cards available to all players makes winning on the flop incredibly common. Worker placement feels pidgin, with forest spaces and meadow spaces providing so many replacements that the interaction never feels meaningful.

This game falls into the category of numerous worker placement games without offering anything new.
Pretty but dull.

- Demasiado azar en el mercado (2° parte) para "combear" parejas de animalitos...esa carta que nunca sale.
- No es recomendable jugar a 2 ya que el mercado se estanca porque no hay suficiente movimiento en el mercado.

Es preferible el juego Mi pequeño Everdell ya que quita todos los puntos negativos incluyendo la duración y el azar del mercado dejando una esencia similar.

Overall, there are many better games to play, perhaps not as good looking as Everdell, but much better for play in a group of two and providing much more fun than this crap.

Two: some of the text is so small I literally didn't notice it and ran the monastery a half dozen times (it's limited and I basically ruined the game scoring). Three: Didn't know there were 'attack' cards that fill up your city. Had a plan and when about to fill last space with a great card, friend swooped in and ended my game at the start of my 3rd round. So I sat out the last half of the game with nothing to do. Why the #$%$# are there attack cards in this sort game? So a 'no interaction game' unless they just randomly screw your game. It doesn't even help them, solely pain to ONE other person. And only TWO in the deck? That makes it worse, small odds with devastating results. BLAH! Really could not get into this game, I’m not sure why 
Very sad as I had high hopes.

Bad production that gets in the way of playing.

The game itself is largely solo, your opponents just exist to refill the market occasionally. Ultimately, like most of these things, you should just play race for the galaxy instead.

Edit: I’ll try not to rant about too much more but I had very similar complaints. Some of it might also have been down to playing it between Santiago and Roll for the Galaxy (one is my favourite games and the other actually understands what engine building games should be).

1) overall production: stupid useless tree that literally just gets in the way. Super small text + hard to read fonts + a game that almost entirely depends on reading the text. One component literally rolls away!

2) the game is aggressively solitaire. Our only interaction was either accidental (“oh you took that card but I needed it because it randomly combos with a card I drew on turn one!”) or one player reminding another player it was their turn.

3) it’s all just about converting resources into points by building randomly drawn cards or from claiming random bonuses that are tied to the random cards. The entire strategy seemed to be get good cards in your opening hand and then get good cards randomly from the market. The actual worker placement gaining resource system seemed almost pointless.

4) maybe if this game was ranked in the 800s I wouldn’t care but this thing is one of the best games of all time?! And people bought a giant expensive big box edition?! Absolutely ridiculous!

2019-02-12 : First game. Worker placement + tableau building card combination game. Looks like a kiddy game, but has some teeth. I liked how each player plays the game at his own pace, you can even already start the next round, there's no waiting for players to end their round. What irked me is that in a game that's so dependent on card combinations, they've done it again : font size 2 text that you're then supposed to be able to read across the table.
2019-02-22 : Another couple of games and the main weakness of the game becomes more clear : it's all about the card combinations and if you don't get them, you'll lose. In other words : between equally competent players luck of the draw will be the deciding factor. Rating slides from "8" to "6"
2021-10-03 : Dan Yarrington & Etsy : I've just ceased and desisted rating this game a "6", it's now a "2"

The main thing is about to get cards which will get you ressources and matching buildings with creatures. If you can't get those you're out. No chance against other who can build such combos. And building those is pure luck.

The cards look nice, but that doesn't make a good game. And it's a multiplayer solitaire par excellence! Nobody cares what the other do.

Overproduced, too simple, not very original, too random and the illustrations are very childish, some argue that they are very beautiful, I do not see depth or artistic interest. The tree is the worst component I have ever seen in a board game: unnecessary, it deteriorates easily and makes it difficult to see cards. The game lacks depth, rhythm, and is anti-climactic. In the opinion of other users, the expansions are expensive and unnecessary. I honestly do not understand the success of this game, perhaps it is due to that "Oh, it's so beautiful" that many argue. I don't see interest in it either as a family game (there are many better ones), or as a starter game or as a filler or as a party. An opportunistic game that thanks to copying mechanics, simplicity and childish aesthetics has managed to convince many casual players. Finally, comment that the history included in the rulebook is up to the game, that is, stupid and not very elaborate.

This is like Splendor if it was much, much more annoying.

As in Splendor, the core gameplay is you sit in pensive silence, taking turns to draft resources from a pool and then put those resources back to purchase cards. The cards grant you additional resources/discounts for future card purchases, as well as victory points.

Here are Everdell's innovations:
- All the cards have unique text on them to read, evaluate, and consider, and you'll often be studying 16 of them at once (8 in your closed hand, 8 in the open shared area).
- In addition, there are 22 worker placement spots on the board alone, and more will be added around the table in players' card tableaus (accessible by walking around the table and peering over people's shoulders). The ponderousness of the decision space will delight anyone who enjoys a lot of downtime between their turns.
- Players don't reach the end of the game at the same time, so some of them will have to wait for the others to finish. "I'm going to the bathroom or something," you'll say, getting up and pulling out your phone as the other players continue dragging out their turns, which never involved you anyway. "Call me back over when it's time to fill out the big spreadsheet."
- You find out who wins not with a nail-biting cross of the finish line, but by filling out a big spreadsheet.
- Instead of tidy stacks of poker chips, the resources are messy piles of plastic toys.

If a game's gonna be multiplayer solitaire busywork, it'd be nice it was at least elegant.

Too much luck to feel like decisions matter, and a long play time. I find I really don't care who wins, and wish the game had taken 1 - 2 hours less. Ability of players to deny overpowered cards in the market is very limited - so it just feels like the decisions are obvious and the game plays itself. Really boring!
Nice components, shame about the heavy luck for me, I just can't see the point in playing.

[ SEE MY UPDATE! ] I don't understand why they designed it so that players can proceed on different timelines. One player can remove themself from the game early and this sets the bar for how many points the other players have to beat in order to win. They get to watch for potentially quite awhile as other people play, with them having nothing to do except watch and wait. If this isn't bad enough, a game about forest critters where they don't scurry around doing a ton of stuff in each season. In Spring and Summer they do 2 and 3 things. That's.... not scurrying. That's not busy. We expected each season to be substantial. Instead Spring is over in 5 minutes, Summer in 10, Autumn in 30?, and Winter can really drag on as the game increases in complexity as each player builds their village and gains more of an engine / options to consider. Aesthetics: perfect. Game Design: all three of us hated it. We kept checking the rules to see if we were missing something. The rulebook isn't great either. But no, this one is not for us.

UPDATE: We played this a second time a year later, on Tabletopia. I was convinced I must have played it wrong. We didn't. We just ALL got TERRIBLE hands of cards that really ruined our first impression of the game, crippling us entirely and spoiling the game. In this second play we all got fantastic combos in our first hand of cards, and we were able to build upon that at a steady and methodical pace through the seasons, chaining combo after combo after combo together. After 2 hours we were all convinced it's a game we should own and keep in our regular game night rotation. What a swing, from a D to an A in one play. Geez. So glad we gave it a second chance!

[UPDATE AGAIN] Oh man... this game is swingy. We've played it twice more and in both of those games 1-2 players got really unlucky card draws, and 1-2 players got incredibly lucky card draws. How one player's experience with a game can swing so drastically from one play session to another through no mistake of their own seems really off-putting to me. In our last two plays, 1-2 players finished early and had to wait 20 minutes or so for the game to wrap up. I spent the entirety of the last two games frustrated that I couldn't get an engine going, my resources were always sparse, and being able to see across the table at "The Joneses" living it up just made me feel like I was destined for a bad time and they were blessed by the Evertree. In the end, the scores were all within a few points of each other, which almost makes it worse? All of their apparent success (and FUN during the game!) didn't actually translate into points, where my lack of fun somehow worked out almost as well? With a great hand of cards, this game sings. With a mediocre hand, few resources, no combos, few workers, ...it's a real slog. I'm going back to a negative opinion of this one. People keep saying "You don't like it because it's not the game you want it to be." Maybe? I want it to be fun every time I play it. I have plenty of games where it's fun to play and lose, but this one can somehow manage to be unpleasant to win. I really wanted this game to be great, but the randomness of card draws is just too much. I've thought about house rules like Mulligans or draw over 8 and discard down, but that's something that should have been sorted out in play-testing. I'd rather go play something else than fix this to my liking. Blah... I'm so annoyed that I don't like this game!

I should probably mention that the 4 of us in our game group do not agree on this. We had a 45 minute discussion that carried over into the following day. The guy who got a good hand of cards in each of the 3 games he's played is the one in love with the game. I suggested he try playing my hand and see how it feels. 

Also, there are a lot of comments suggesting that "once you learn the deck and what the combos are, the game opens up, you know what to look for, the chains are more obvious, it's less random, etc etc." Maybe I really dislike card games... I don't want to learn your deck. I want to play a strategy game where my skill and wits are the deciding factor, not the card draw. I can't shake the feeling that if this game did not have worker placement, I wouldn't confuse it with a strategy game and I'd approach it like a card game.... but I already know I don't prefer card games... so that probably wouldn't help either.

UPDATE: played 4p again, this time with a few random starting resources and everybody starts with a farm in their starting hand, in an attempt to loosen things up a bit. I also chose mainly resource generating clearing cards. I really can't stand this game. I only tried it again because a friend really loves it and hoped that this variant would fix some issues, but I hate everything except the artwork with this game. One player managed to tread water in Winter while the rest of us were in Summer. He nearly doubled our scores and there was almost nothing we could have done to improve our scores. The entire game you are reminded that you aren't performing nearly as well as someone else. Yes, that same thing happens when you have a common score track and you're trailing behind, but sometimes there's an investment strat you can employ that rockets you back into the running. Everdell feels bad to play when the artwork suggests that it should feel like the coziest game out in existence. This game breaks my heart. I can't stand the design decisions here. The only reason I don't score it lower is because I'm still willing to play it with this friend... I just have to constant remind myself that it's for his benefit, not mine, and to keep my thoughts to myself so I don't ruin his fun.

Sorry, I don't like this at all. This is tableau building taken to its worst because you need that card to work with this card. That card comes up, but is immediately taken by the person in front of you, OR you don't have the resources to buy it, so again it is gone before your turn comes around again. It isn't just one card needs another, it's Every card needs another card. Way, way, way too random and takes way, way, way too long!
Every 4 player game I've seen played of this has taken at least 2 hours and sometimes even three! And downtime is IMMENSE! Nothing to like about this game. And to top it off the card text is TINY! Everyone is trying to read the cards in the meadow, but it always comes down to picking up the card and reading it, or having someone read it to you. There are worse games, so this only gets a 3, but I will never play again.
Also, how can an expansion make it better? It would just make it more confusing, longer, and more frustrating by requiring even more cards that need other cards.

Very modern euro-aesthetic design. Animal themed art, high production value, low interaction, meaningless point salad elements.

The board state for other players is just completely unreadable, the worker placement is very uninspired, and the point salad is so over-balanced it is meaningless. I'm assuming every game ends with all players around 51 points by default, and it is whomever manages to eek out the few extra to get to 60 wins.

Instead of a grid where every card is a drip of points, just concentrate it to make it more readable.

It's not a bad game, but i don't ever want to play it again.
It's just not fun.
It's a mean efficiency puzzle for people who like to min-max and analyse as much as possible - can you squeeze out anything useful from what you have available ? nothing good ? you still have to do something.
So there's many actions that feel bad, unrewarding. I don't feel like i've achieved anything, just barley scraped by a few more points.

And there's so few actions that you can't get a good engine rolling. Once you have "Something", the game is over.

Some people might like that, but i don't.

3/5

It's my first review here, so of course it's for a game I have a lot of issues with.

- Aesthetics are beautiful, but they don't match the gameplay. Game design is cute, but gameplay is far from cute. You are playing through 3 seasons... and every player plays in their own alternative universe, since you can end a season earlier, meaning you can be playing in autumn, and someone will be still in summer or potentially even in spring.
- Random card draws. There were games where we haven't seen a single husband and games where one player had 3 sets of farm+husband+wife
- Playing free cards, if you have good luck drawing, is incredibly unbalanced.
- the game lets the most humble player start, and there is nothing humble in this game. You rush for limited spots for production, try to get good cards before other players get them, even if you are not planning to play that card. Just because you don't want other players to have it. There is resource sharing, but only if you are forced to do it.
- Goals often carry the game but since they are limited (and you have to spend a worker to get a single one) other players might steal them from you
- Decision paralysis trigger. You have limited amount of workers, limited amount of "good" spots for them, and by the end of the game limit of cards you can have in your city. So the last turns I spend overthinking if I can fit some more cards, and which ones
- Some places for workers are on other players cards. Keeping track of them is a headache and reading the effect

+ Resources are super. Berries are squishy, and amber see through
+ "Take that" card is actually nice for me. It's one of the few player interactions that are intentional. You have a countermeasure that gets rid of it, if you are lucky to draw it, lucky to gave resources and lucky to have a free spot in the city.

Overall, it's a worker placement game where you're deciding which of all bad options you can take. Unless you have luck in drawing cards and everything goes your way, then you know you won in the middle of the game.

I plan to play it again with house rule which splits meadow cards into 4 stacks of normal creatures, normal buildings, unique creatures and unique buildings.

2 Plays
9/29/19
Interesting engine-builder with really pleasing art. Needs more plays to properly evaluate. There seems to exist significant depth. Also significant randomness. But the 1 play makes me wonder if the at least some portion of the randomness can be overcome to some extent with skill. The season progress challenge is pretty interesting as well. Probably a game that will be significantly better if playing with a group that plays it often. Still rates lower than Terraforming Mars at the end of the day I suppose (as an engine builder); and I do not really like TFM.

11/6/19
Feedback remains the same. The expansions do make the game a bit more interesting I suppose. But yea.. a lot depends on the card draw and player order. Player order issue gets masked by the card draw issue, but I feel that the lower number of cards to start with is not really a sufficient handicap. The card art does look absolutely spectacular though. And the board is not terrible either. And the box looks pretty good too. Rating after first play, 4p: 3/10.
Cute critters in solitaire town.
Bad: Too much luck of the draw, too much hard to read card text, and too little direct or interesting player interaction. The only attack card I saw in play (The Fool) seemed too strong, and cards that let you use other players' cards are cumbersome because of how hard it is to read other players' tableaus. Comboing can make turns long and forces heads down play to execute well. Long game. If you finish early you must wait for other (probably better) players to finish before the game ends, which can mean several rounds of play.
Good: Tight starting economy. Limited number of cards in hand and in your tableau adds an interesting restriction that you have to plan around (again, The Fool can really mess up a player's game). Artwork and bits are nice. Pulling of combos can be fun. The open market mitigates some of the luck dependence.
Verdict: Le Havre and Agricola are still the best worker placement games of this kind to me, when it comes to building your personal board or tableau. Everdell has some nice things going for it, but ultimately feels to bloated and solitaire to compete. But if you want a combination of classic worker placement and personal tableau building with some twists, crazy components and generally non-aggressive play, Everdell is worth checking out.

A very pretty but convoluted game. It's a perfect example of what's plaguing board games today: all flash, no substance, all algorithm.

The 3D tree where you track seasons, keep your pawns and bonuses, is totally useless. It could simply be an extended part of the flat board. It's just there for show.

The theme could just as easily been Dante's Seven Levels of Hell, or Charlie and the Chocolate Factory, which isn't a good thing, because all it shows is that the mechanics were done first, the theme at the very end during some marketing meeting.

There's too much to keep in mind. There are 4 materials you can use to build stuff, because, "hey, other games have 3, so we will have 4!" The instructions on some cards you play are so bloated, it forces the more normal players to simply avoid using them. Each card you draw has over a dozen elements on them, and many have interwoven effects on one another, so using the cards require quite a bit of memory. "Did I use that card? Can I use it again? What can I use it with? Will it affect the final score? Can others use my card?"

On the positive side, you have to carefully choose which card you play because others can take advantage of them, the art is great, the 3D tree looks awesome on Instagram, but once you really think about it, man, what a let-down.

All we want is that developers design their games theme first. mechanics later. We want to have fun PLAYING THE GAME, NOT LEARNING THE GAME OR BRAGGING ABOUT THEM ON SOCIAL MEDIA!

On the tasks, in the places, there are a lot of cards with text that should be remembered, because we want to actively use these cards and places. Access to the cards is made more difficult for more people. We have the cards at home, in the meadow in front of us, etc.. it's a disaster. This is not compensated by the gameplay, because despite the cards in the hand and on the board, randomness is very high. At the beginning you may have perfect cards, other people may be blocked, etc.
Another disadvantage is the tree, which cannot be stored in the box after folding and unfolding, it breaks down after folding and unfolding, and above all, it is unnecessary, inconvenient/clunky, it adds nothing to the game and only gets in the way when something falls off it.
There is no strategy here, this game is so random that even if you plan something at the beginning of the round, when it is your turn, there may be nothing left of your plans. The cards have changed, the fields have been occupied, if you wait for some related cards, they may never appear. This game supposedly requires thinking, but you can't plan anything, it's pure randomness.
The game attracts attention, with a nice appearance and nice workmanship, that's all it takes, the inconvenience of the tree, random cards, problems with card handling, etc. I don't understand the phenomenon of this game at all. I think it might be the price. The game may be sold as a medium-sized, nicely made family game, at a good price, for people who do not pay much attention to randomness and are more focused on doing something with their family, even if it is unbalanced, random, etc..

It could be the case that this "wasn't for us". But honestly I felt that it was simply bad.

The production is "good" in the Kickstarter meaning of "good". Realistically the company has had to iterate several times to fix their own choices in over-production. The tree is in the way… it just is. The early wooden logs rolled off the table. The card text is so small as to be unreadable for any distance and the game is designed to encourage you to read the text of other players cards. The game and its expansions cost much more than is justified by the quality of the game and the company has gone to great lengths to extract as much as possible from both their core fans and those weak to the hype cycle around the game. A behavior for which I don't blame them for but which I think consumers might be justifiably weary.

What's more the core game mechanisms just don't come together that well in my opinion. There are whole features that simply don't play out in _most_ games. Card combinations that you might hunt for but probably won't find either because other players are incentivized to snipe them from you or because those cards simply don't show.

Everdell is undeniably adorable. The woodland critter theme is consistently illustrated and visually charming, with lovely card art and whimsical components. But once you look past the cute veneer, the theme feels fairly generic. It’s essentially humans in animal form. The anthropomorphism comes off more as a cosmetic layer than a deeply integrated world. The 3D tree, while eye-catching on the table, is clunky to use and annoying to store.

As an engine builder, it’s okay. Some satisfying combos can emerge, but after 4 or 5 plays, it still hasn’t fully clicked. The core gameplay often feels restrictive, with tight limits on resources, cards in hand, and city space. Instead of enjoying the process of building something, you’re mostly working around constraints.

The rulebook doesn’t help either. It’s padded with thematic fluff but lacks clarity, and I had to Google several mechanics that should have been straightforward. To make matters worse, my copy arrived without the solo mode dice, and the rulebook binding started falling apart after just two sessions. While the game looks premium at first glance, I’m not confident in its long-term production quality.

Surprised by the high rating to be honest because underneath the slightly cutesy theme there's nothing mechanically here that's new. Gather resources with workers, pay them to 'build' cards, the winner will be the one who best combines cards together - with the caveat that luck can play a big part in what cards you're able to build.

All that said though, Everdell does what it does pretty well, offering small ways to mitigate that luck of the draw and crucially, not outstaying its welcome (as long as you're not playing with the AP-prone). So whilst it doesn't do anything special, it's still an enjoyable game. And it does look very nice too, if you don't mind the fact the board's not hugely functional - you might well end up peering around a cardboard tree.

Great production. The artwork is nice and immersive, and I like how the resources have their own textures (rubber berries, acrylic resin, wood twigs, smooth pebbles).

Great and easy-to-understand iconography. The rulebook is easy to follow, but I think it could be a little more detailed. It wasn't clear off the bat what exactly we were supposed to do, which is to build a city to get as many points as we could. It required a playthrough to fully flesh out the details.

Decent theme. Everything seems to flow well and tie together in an understandable way. The theme helps to understand the mechanisms well (e.g. each round represents a season; the card abilities make sense based on the critter/construction; a construction can house only one critter and when used to play a critter / add the critter to your city, you use a "locked in / closed door" token on the construction to indicate that that construction is occupied and can not be used to add another critter into the city for free; etc.).

Very strategic and thinky. Feels like there'd be a lot of analysis paralysis and downtime waiting for people to think, so playing with 3+ players might result in a lot of waiting around. It does feel a bit like multiplayer solitaire, with most of the player interactions coming from blocking other players from getting a resource that they want. Players move at their own pace and progress through the seasons individually (they don't wait for all other players before starting the next season), which I thought would make things confusing, but when playing with 2 players, we found that we weren't ever more than 1 season apart from one another. We weren't completely in sync, but we were not far from one another ever.

Because there are only 4 seasons, just a handful of workers, and just 1 action per turn, the number of total actions you can play in a game feels limited, so I felt like I really needed to maximize my points in the limited number of actions that I had. Involves a lot of thinking through every possible thing to find the best thing to do that would gain the most points. There are a lot of things to think about: events, card combos, meadow cards (i.e. the cards laid out shown in public for display), etc. Involves a bit of reading (of the card abilities) to know your options. In general, involves keeping track of cards to get the best combination of cards to maximize points (as a result of the set collection mechanism).

I think there's good replayability. There seems to be a lot of different cards in the deck and enough variability in setup that keeps each game feeling fresh. I can see how after a few plays (maybe like 4), the strategies and card combinations can start feeling the same, so expansions would really help keep each game feeling like a different experience.

Overall, I like this game because of the theme and cozy artwork. I'd have to be in a certain mood to play -- one where I want to think a lot. It's a great game, but for me, it's just one in the mix of "good game" options. It doesn't stick out to me too much. I do like this game more than and think I'd choose to play this game over Wingspan because I think there's more player interaction and challenge.

Cute, thematic game where all the pieces come together in a very cohesive way. Heavier than it looks, Everdell rewards multiple playthroughs, but the charming aesthetic and intuitive ruleset make every play an enjoyable experience.

Overall - 8/10 - Best at 2 players
I played Everdell three times - twice at 2 players and once at 6 (!) players with the Bellfaire expansion. I enjoyed it each time, but it's so similar to other games I own (Wingspan, Terraforming Mars) that I don't feel like it has a place in my collection.


Theme - 2/2

+ This game is as thematic as it gets - a cozy-looking forest game board (complete with a giant pop-up tree), fancy resource tokens, and great artwork on the cards.

+ Critters go out and gather resources for you, forest buildings are constructed, and specific critters want to live in them. Everything you do feels like part of the theme.


Rules - 1.5/2

+ The rules are generally simple - you place workers to gather resources, then use those resources to play cards from your hand or the display. Anyone familiar with similar games, like Wingspan, should catch on quickly.

- Those that haven’t played similar games may struggle with understanding everything, especially when it comes to players being on different seasons, what makes cards trigger, etc.


Turn Simplicity - 1.75/2

+ Playing a turn is simple - place a worker, play a card, or pass (prepare for next season).

+ Resources are tight, so players should generally know what they want to do on their turn, though there are a lot of things on the board to distract them.


Fun Factor - 1.25/2

+ Finding critter cards that you can play for free because they want to “occupy” one of your buildings, feels like a unique part of Everdell and is very fun.

+ The game has a nice ramp up from barely being able to play a card or two to triggering most of your city and getting extra resources, actions, etc.

- Worker placement feels a bit lacking. Players will generally fight over the same few spots because they have the most valuable resources (e.g., an extra pebble), but there aren’t enough workers or rounds to make it very strategic.

- Cards have extremely small text, making it very hard to read things in the “meadow” (shared card area). Plays occasionally just took whatever because they didn’t feel like leaning over that area again.

In the end, it was a well-designed and interesting game, but just didn't have anything new to offer for a group that had played a lot of Wingspan and Viticulture. We hoped that Everdell would be a great blend of those two games, but it ended up feeling like a watered-down version of both.


Challenge and Replayability - 1.5/2

+ Making the most of the resources you can get is a standard puzzle for card-based engine builders, but is no less fun and challenging here.

+ A huge deck of cards and bonus tiles makes the game extremely replayable; there are also a ton of expansions available to make it even more so.

- Those who already have games with similar mechanics, like Wingspan, Viticulture, or Terraforming Mars may find that Everdell is a bit watered-down; the worker placement is very light and there are a lot of card “pairings” which limits just how much variety you’ll see in a game.

the game is just terrific! we used to own the basic game and a couple expansions before the complete collection was released, so you will see a similar review there. it is effectively put together, making incredible variability for strategies that all have the potential to win.

it is worker placement, resource gathering, tableau building in their finest forms. the few workers you have feel so valuable when you lay them, but yield you only a little, such that you really depend on combinations of good plays to deleop through the available cards and special abilities. this makes for a lot more excitement than just gather resources and build the most obvious things. the changing of the seasons adds urgency to the game and there is a benefit to choosing to move slowly and a benefit to progress first.

we have not even referenced how cute the game is. the art is fantastic! the themes they string together are excellent. you can easily sort out what the makers were going for when giving each card its ability. the extra mechanics that come along with the expansions are very worth buying for added variability. the only expansion that gets ignored a lot is pearlbrook, and that, mostly because the pearls are pretty powerful. everdell easily belongs among the best games ever made. we could not recommend it enough.

the 10+ age recommendation is close. our formerly 10 year old got by well enough, though there was an amount of missed efficiency, without some help. 12+ might be better. the 40-80 minutes feels a bit low. some of our games push 2 hours, but our gaming groups have little people, we make games the background of the game days, and we often pause for conversations and real life.

Everdell – Easily one of the most beautiful games you’ll ever put on your table, with the majestic Evertree towering in the center like a fairy-tale landmark. You lead a charming cast of woodland critters as they build and grow their bustling little city, constructing buildings, inviting new residents, and carefully managing resources to reach key milestones. The game’s card-driven engine blends perfectly with classic worker placement mechanics, creating a smooth and engaging pacing that feels both strategic and whimsical. It’s the kind of game that looks as good as it plays — a true delight for players who love a mix of clever tactics and cozy storytelling in a stunning package.

Everything just clicks for me. I've played it many times and I love the way it builds up. You start off not being able to do much, but then you get your tableau and workers going and all of a sudden you are off to the races, finding new and cool combinations with your cards.

I think I originally had this game at a 8.5 but after coming back to it time and time again over the years it is honestly a 10. It will always be in my collection and I am excited to share it with new people every time.

One of my favorites in the collection. A lot of things to do, which in the beginning seems even daunting, and you get a feeling that there's never enough resources to get what you want. But after a round or two the engine starts turning and you are able to make some pretty satisfying combos. Looks and plays great. Doesn't take too long, which makes it easy to put on the table on regular basis. It is a bit heavier on the rules - especially for people new to board games - but in the end it's usually a pleasure to go through both with experienced and new players.

I enjoy an overproduced game that is interactive, worker placement and engine building. My only complaint is that the players I play this with are much much better than I am. It's also Very Long!! Played with a "chess Timer". which was fun, challenging and moved the game along.

What a beautiful game! The artwork is lovely, the components are amazing, and even that inconveniently large tree provides some real table presence. This game is not merely pretty, it's also an excellent worker placement and tableau building game with a plethora of exciting expansions. I have the Big Box but I've decanted my favorite elements into the original box as my Everdell Essentials Edition. For those who are curious that includes Extra Extra Extra (Collector's Edition), Creature Powers (Bellfaire), generic special events (Bellfaire and others), and all the Forest Locations. Each of the expansions gives a different flavor to the game, allowing Everdell to become something of a game system which you can customize to your liking. Want a tighter game, try Spirecrest with just the base game. Want an open high-scoring game, use Newleaf and all its modules. I prefer it to be a bit tighter, which you'll see in my "Essential Edition".
